Off- 0*R*Navy 3,419 375,130 689 2,806 14,6311 211,609 10,608 28,236my 171,900 3,544,000 3,947 37,377 97,495 2,525.509 17,105 * jUF. 27,100 251,000 329 1,232 15,519 191,092 4,707 6,971Imtmn jlituriiiinri. -m mi mm i mt* tinfii r-irn-ihUf minister'**--Ttrn *"1*f *" "" 1 " ' *i "'*" - -- '"r - ^-p- iiani in*T*iir*,*cnn)n i*rnimririiTiri *wtm* hhmixm iiiiiihwh iditiiiwmiMiiD-M-MU-wWiifWiu r infin irtnT^nwtwi i Hi'fAl*. 234,419.4*170,130*4,966* 41,415.127,825. 2,928,210. 32,420k This figure has not yet been supplied by tho Vhr Office-leraploymani.The number of 0ut-of-l.ork Donation Policies remaining lodged the 20th June, wag 645,096,' as compared with 664,829, at the 13th June, fall of 19,733 for the week. Civilian Policies lodged are fewer by ,212, but there is an increase of 2,479, in the number of H.K.Foroes Holes lodged, corresponding with a recent slight increase in the(rate demobilisation * The reduction of Civilian Policies lu 6,978 for Men, ,929 for Vomen, and 1,307 for Juveniles. The figures are shewn in tenso in Appendix 1.An analysis by Industries of the Policies lodged Is furnished Appendix 2* The only considerable increases in une iployment fire in o Textiles - "Other" - Group which includes Linen, Silk, and Jute, aa 11 as Printing and Dyeing, and the General Labourers Group. On the her hand Engineering and Ironfounding, omd the Domestic Offices and rvices group shew heavy reductions. 155Short Time.Appendix 3 gives the position in regard to Short Time at tho 15th,June, The number of Workers on Short Time is 22,000 lower than it was a week before; this amounts to a fall of 26. percent. There is increased Short Time among Workers in dross, almost the whole increase being in Ireland, On the other hand the Irish Linen Industry has nearly 17,000 fewer workers on Short Time,Disabled Sailora . Soldisre, and Airmen,The operations of Exchanges in respect of Disabled men during the four weeks ended the 6th,June are shown in Appendix 40 The number of such'-en placed in. employment is greater by 600 than that for the previous month. It is noticeable that out of about 640s000 men handled by the Ministry of Pensions less than 40,000 remain on the Live Register at Exchanges as candidates for employmenta4.VII..W.
